awd_titl_txt: Actively Managed Battery Degradation of IoT Wireless Sensors for Group Replacement
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will enhance the Nation's competitiveness by reducing life cycle costs of battery-powered wireless devices that constitute networked sensor systems.  Networked sensor systems are integral to emerging Internet of Things (IoT) applications in such diverse domains as manufacturing systems and civil infrastructure systems.  Battery life continues to limit network performance.  This project will investigate system-level performance improvements through individual battery management and group replacement strategies.  By monitoring and controlling individual battery usage, system level quality of service can be dynamically adjusted, leading to more uniform useful battery life.  When these networked systems are located in remote locations, cost-effective group replacement policies can lead to lower costs to maintain the network.  The project will involve graduate students and will include mentoring activities to attract students from underrepresented groups.

The project is expected to advance the state of the art in the following aspects: (1) a prognostic algorithm that accurately predicts battery remaining useful life, using transfer learning to leverage condition monitoring data of all batteries in a connected environment; (2) a novel predictive maintenance policy designed for battery group replacement, enabled by active management of battery degradation processes; (3) optimal scheduling of battery maintenance activities under the presence of another independently managed maintenance program with higher priority. The project will advance knowledge on battery health management in connected environments and provide effective power management strategies for battery-powered wireless IoT devices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Arizona Board of Regents, University of Arizona

por.por_cntn:
IoT applications often rely on wireless sensors in remote locations where maintenance is costly and challenging. While energy harvesting methods like solar and wind power can extend sensor battery life, the finite lifespan of batteries remains a key limitation, requiring periodic replacements. Ideally, uniform battery degradation across the network would allow for coordinated replacements, reducing maintenance efforts and costs. However, battery degradation varies due to differences in duty cycles, environmental factors, communication challenges, hardware issues, and capacity uncertainties.

This project aimed to develop an adaptive battery management framework to extend battery lifespan, ensure uniform degradation across the network, and maintain the desired quality of service (QoS). A multidisciplinary team was assembled: systems engineering experts focused on degradation modeling, battery simulation, and reliability analysis, while civil engineers contributed expertise in wireless sensor networks, energy harvesting, and machine learning for system health monitoring.

As a foundational effort, we developed an adaptive preventive maintenance policy to minimize long-term costs, leveraging a joint modeling framework for degradation and dynamic reliability prediction. This approach, refined with real-time monitoring data, schedules inspection intervals and maintenance actions based on updated reliability predictions. Numerical studies show the Adaptive Sequential Preventive Maintenance (ASPM) policy significantly reduces hard failures and costs compared to time-based maintenance (TBM).

Building on this foundation, the adaptive framework was enhanced to manage a network of batteries with diverse workloads, specifically focusing on wireless sensor networks (WSNs) for structural health monitoring. A duty-cycling optimization strategy was developed to synchronize battery degradation, enabling group replacements while maintaining network QoS. Incorporating calendar aging and duty-cycle degradation, the model predicted battery capacity loss and estimated remaining useful life (RUL). A case study based on prior research for impact load identification validated the approach by dynamically adjusting sensor configurations on a 9-bay truss structure equipped with 10 sensors. The study demonstrated significant extension of the sensor network lifespan, with batteries achieving nearly uniform end-of-life times, without compromising the accuracy of impact load estimations, preserving network QoS.

To address more complex scenarios, a reinforcement learning (RL)-based framework was also investigated, capable of dynamically managing battery degradation under real-world uncertainties. A realistic degradation model tailored for lithium-ion NMC batteries was integrated into the framework, accounting for various uncertainty factors such as varying depths of discharge, initial charge levels, and solar variability. A structural-mode shape-based quality metric, Modal Assurance Criteria (MAC), was introduced to evaluate QoS in structural health monitoring WSNs. The RL framework was validated through a real-world case study of a WSN deployed on the Jindo Bridge, a cable-stayed bridge in South Korea. A full-scale study involving up to 54 deck sensors under varying conditions demonstrated a network lifespan increase of over 30% compared to traditional schedule-based operation, while maintaining high MAC values.

To further enhance QoS, a data imputation method was also developed to recover missing sensor data. This method learns data patterns from active sensors to estimate missing information. This capability provides the sensor network with additional flexibility to adjust the network duty cycle through controlled sensor activation/deactivation, enabling energy-efficient operation. A graph-based model captured spatial dependencies among sensors, and a Bayesian inference-based algorithm optimized parameter learning for accurate imputation. The Jindo Bridge case study highlighted superior data recovery and robustness, demonstrating the method's ability to improve network flexibility and robustness, promoting uniform battery degradation.

In summary, we employed a multifaceted approach to address the research objective of developing an adaptive battery management framework capable of extending battery lifespan, achieving uniform battery degradation across entire IoT sensor networks, without compromising the desired quality of service (QoS) of the network. Our contributions include:

Adaptive Preventive Maintenance Policy: Established as a baseline study, this policy minimizes long-term maintenance costs through adaptive monitoring and maintenance scheduling.

Optimization Framework: Designed to manage networks of batteries, this framework synchronizes battery degradation while maximizing network lifespan and maintaining QoS.

Reinforcement Learning-Based Method: Developed to address more realistic and complex scenarios, this method dynamically adapts to uncertainties, promoting energy efficiency and uniform battery degradation.

Data Imputation Method: Created to recover missing data from inactive or malfunctioning sensors, this method ensures network QoS and enhances flexibility in managing the network duty cycle.

All these advancements were rigorously validated through comprehensive case studies, including a real-world wireless sensor network deployed on a cable-stayed bridge, demonstrating the effectiveness and practicality of the proposed framework.

 


Last Modified: 01/08/2025
Modified by: Hongki Jo
